title: What is React JS?
options: A: A programming language
B: A JavaScript library for building user interfaces
C: A markup language
D: A database management system

title: What is JSX?
options: A: A JavaScript extension
B: A file format used for React components
C: A programming language
D: A library for handling user input

title: What is a component in React JS?
options: A: A file that contains CSS styles
B: A function or class that returns HTML
C: A tool for managing state in React
D: A method for handling user input

title: What is state in React JS?
options: A:A method for updating the DOM
B:An object that holds data in a React component
C: A way to handle user input
D: A library for managing animations

title: What is props in React JS?
options: A: A method for updating the DOM
B: A way to pass data from a parent to a child component
C: A library for managing animations
D: A tool for managing state in React

title: What is the virtual DOM in React JS?
options: A: A way to render components on the server
B: A lightweight version of the DOM used for performance optimization
C: A tool for managing state in React
D: A method for handling user input

title: What is the purpose of React Router?
options: A: To create routes for an application
B: To provide a way to navigate between pages in a single-page application
C: To manage the state of a React component
D: To render React components on the server

title: What is Redux in React JS?
options: A: A library for managing state in React applications
B: A tool for creating responsive user interfaces
C: A way to manage server-side rendering in React
D: A method for handling user input

title: What is the difference between props and state in React JS?
options: A: Props are read-only, while state can be updated
B: State is read-only, while props can be updated
C: Props and state are the same thing
D: Props and state cannot be updated

title: What is React Native?
options: A: A web development framework for React
B: A mobile development framework for React
C: A tool for managing state in React
D: A way to handle user input in React

title: What is a higher-order component in React JS?
options: A: A component that is higher in the component tree
B: A component that takes another component as an argument
C: A component that is higher in the DOM tree
D: A component that is responsible for managing state in React

title: What is the purpose of keys in React?
options: A: To uniquely identify elements in an array
B: To sort elements in an array
C: To filter elements in an array
D: To update elements in an array

title: What is the difference between a controlled and an uncontrolled component in React?
options: A: A controlled component is a component that is directly manipulated by the user, while an uncontrolled component is not
B: An uncontrolled component is a component that is directly manipulated by the user, while a controlled component is not
C: A controlled component is a component that is not directly manipulated by the user, while an uncontrolled component is
D: There is no difference between controlled and uncontrolled components

title: What is the purpose of React.memo in React JS?
options: A: To memoize a React component
B: To prevent unnecessary re-renders of a React component
C: To manage the state of a React component
D: To handle user input in a React component

title: What is the purpose of the useContext hook in React JS?
options: A: To memoize a React component
B: To prevent unnecessary re-renders of a React component
C: To manage the state of a React component
D: To share data between React components without using props

title: What is the purpose of the useCallback hook in React JS?
options: A: To memoize a React component
B: To prevent unnecessary re-renders of a React component
C: To manage the state of a React component
D: To optimize performance by caching function instances

title: What is the purpose of the useRef hook in React JS?
options: A: To memoize a React component
B: To prevent unnecessary re-renders of a React component
C: To manage the state of a React component
D: To access the DOM element of a React component

title: What is the difference between class and functional components in React?
options: A: Class components use a class definition while functional components use a function definition
B: Class components can have state while functional components cannot
C: Class components use the this keyword while functional components do not
D: All of the above

title: What is the purpose of the useReducer hook in React?
options: A: To manage complex state in a more organized and predictable way
B: To handle user input in a React component
C: To memoize a function and only recreate it when its dependencies change
D: To prevent unnecessary re-renders of a React component

title: What is the purpose of render() in React?
options: A: To define the structure and appearance of a React component
B: To handle user input in a React component
C: To manage the state of a React component
D: To render the component into the DOM

title: What is an arrow function in React JS?
options: A: A function that uses the 'function' keyword
B: A function that uses the 'arrow' symbol (=>) instead of the 'function' keyword
C: A function that can only be used in React class components
D: A function that is used to define state in React

title: What is an event in React?
options: A: A user interaction with a React component
B: A data structure used for managing state in React
C: A JavaScript function used for rendering components in React
D: A styling framework used for designing React components

title: Explain the life cycle methods of React components.
options: A: Methods that execute on every render of a component
B: Methods that execute during the mounting and unmounting of a component
C: Methods that execute during the updating of a component's props or state
D: Methods that execute during the handling of user events in a component

title: What do you understand by refs in React?
options: A: A way to reference an element in the DOM
B: A component lifecycle method
C: A tool for managing state in React
D: A method for handling user input in React

title: What are Higher Order Components(HOC) in React?
options: A: Components that are rendered higher up in the component tree
B: Components that are used to pass data from parent to child components
C: Components that are used to manage state in a React application
D: Components that are used to wrap other components to enhance or modify their behavior

title: What can you do with Higher Order Components (HOC) in React?
options: A: Reuse component logic
B: Manipulate props of a component
C: Abstract away common functionality
D: All of the above

title: What are Pure Components in React?
options: A: Components that can only render pure HTML
B: Components that are written using pure JavaScript
C: Components that always render the same output for the same input props
D: Components that are optimized for performance using memoization

title: What is Flux in React JS?
options: A: A state management pattern used in React applications
B: A programming language used to build React applications
C: A library used to handle server-side rendering in React
D: A tool used to manage user authentication in React applications

title: What is the significance of keys in React?
options: A: To uniquely identify elements in an array
B: To sort elements in an array
C: To filter elements in an array
D: To update elements in an array

title: What is Redux in React?
options: A: A state management library for JavaScript applications
B: A CSS preprocessor
C: A testing framework for React components
D: A server-side rendering engine for React

title: What are the components of Redux in React?
options: A: Actions
B: Reducers
C: Store, view
D: All of the above

title: In which of the following language React.js is written?
options: A: JavaScript
B: Python
C: Ruby
D: Java

title: Which of the following command is used to Install create-react-app?
options: A: npm install create-react-app
B: npm install -f create-react-app
C: npm install -g create-react-app
D: install -g create-react-app

title: Which of the following is method is not a part of ReactDOM?
options: A: ReactDOM.hydrate()
B: ReactDOM.destroy()
C: ReactDOM.createPortal()
D: All of the mentioned

title: Which of the following is used to pass data to a component from outside in React?
options: A: props
B: render with arguments
C: setState
D: PropTypes

title: Which of the following is correct about prop in React?
options: A: Can be changed inside another component
B: Can be changed inside the component
C: Cannot be changed in the component
D: All of the above

title: What is the correct syntax to write expression in JSX?
options: A: [ expression ]
B: { expression }
C: {{ expression }}
D: _expression

title: In ReactJS, what is State?
options: It's a temporary storage of the elements
It's a state of the execution of the ReactJS application
It's an internal storage of the components
All of the above

title: Which statement is required to define a class component?
options: A: extends React.Components
B: imports React.Components
C: extends React.Component
D: imports React.Component

title: What are components in ReactJS?
options: A: Components are like functions that return HTML elements.
B: Components are the HTML elements.
C: Components are the set of variables defined in ReactJS.
D: None of the above

title: What is the default port where webpack-server runs?
Which method is used to generate lists?
options: A: map()
B: generate()
C: new()
D: maps()

title: With an arrow function, what does the 'this' keyword represent?
options: A: The current object
B: The header object
C: The child object
D: The content

title: Which is the correct arrow function to add two numbers?
options: A. add = (a,b) => a+b;
B. add = (a,b) => return a+b;
C. add = (a,b) => { return a+b;}
D. Both A. and B.
E. Both A. and C.

title: In ES6, why arrow functions are used?
options: A. To access pointer variable
B. To access variable of a class
C. Both A and B
D. Write shorter function syntax

title: A class component must include the _______ statement.
options: A: extends React.Component
B: extends React
C: extends Component
D: extends React.Component.All

title: What is a Redux store?
options: A: A single state tree in a Redux application
B: A collection of multiple state trees in a Redux application
C: A component in a Redux application
D: A stylesheet in a Redux application

title: What is the purpose of Redux in React?
options: A: To manage component state in React applications
B: To manage component styles in React applications
C: To manage component events in React applications
D: To manage global state in React applications

title: How many elements does a React component return?
options: A: 1 Element
B: 2 Elements
C: Multiple Elements
D: None of the above

title: What are the limitations of ReactJS?
options: A: React is only for view layer of the app so we still need the help of other technologies to get a complete tooling set for development
B: React is using inline templating and JSX. This can seem awkward to some developers
C: The library of React is too large
D: All of these

title: What are Props in React?
options: A: Injected
B: Methods
C: Both A and B
D: None of these

title: Which API is a MUST for every ReactJS component?
options: A: getInitialState
B: render
C: renderComponent
D: None of the Above

title: What is the name of the React component that catches JavaScript errors anywhere in the child component tree?
options: A: Error Bosses
B: Error Catchers
C: Error Helpers
D: Error Boundaries

title: In which lifecycle method do you typically make requests for data in a class component?
options: A: constructor
B: componentDidMount
C: componentWillReceiveProps
D: componentWillMount

title: All React components must act like ___ with respect to their props.
options: A: monads
B: pure functions
C: recursive functions
D: higher-order functions

title: What is the purpose of using a ref in React?
options: A: To directly access the DOM node
B: To refer to another JS file
C: To bind the function
D: To call a function

title: What package contains the render() function that renders a React element tree to the DOM?
options: A: React
B: DOM
C: ReactDOM
D: Render

title: What is sent to an Array.map() function?
options: A: a callback function that is called once for each element in the array
B: the name of another array to iterate over
C: the number of times you want to call the function
D: a string describing what the function should do

title: Why is it a good idea to pass a function to setState instead of an object?
options: A: It is more functional than an object
B: It automatically updates a component
C: It makes sure that the object is not mutated
D: setState is asynchronous and might result in out of sync values.

title: What are two ways data gets handled in react?
options: A: state & props
B: services & components
C: state & services
D: state & component

title: What can you use to handle code splitting?
options: A: React.split
B: React.lazy
C: React.memo
D: React.fallback

title: When do you use useLayoutEffect?
options: A) to optimize for all devices
B) to complete the update
C) to change the layout of the screen
D) when you need the browser to paint before the effect runs
